Rule.desc: Mark cookies as HttpOnly
Avoid duplicated forms in the 'validation.xml'
Always call 'super.validate()' from validation methods in 'ActionForm' classes
Do not extend from the Struts classes 'ActionForm' and 'DynaActionForm'
Use 'StringBuffer' instead of 'String' when concatenating strings
Do not hard-code IP addresses and port numbers
Ensure Plugins are added in the 'struts-config.xml'
Implement 'readObject()' and 'writeObject()' for all 'Serializable' classes
Avoid "try", "catch" and "finally" blocks with empty bodies
Avoid "break" and/or "continue" with labels
Do not compare floating point types
Ensure validators are enabled in the 'struts-config.xml'
Do not hard code an absolute pathname when calling a constructor from the 'File' class
Do not hard code '\n' or '\r' as a line separator
Do not use "java.awt.peer.*" interfaces directly
Avoid literal constants
Use wrapper methods to secure native methods
Do not use user-defined "native" methods
Include a meaningful file header comment in every source file
Declare variables as close as possible to where they are used
Protect against HTTP response splitting
Protect against Library injection
Inspect usage of standard API calls that bypass security
Protect against log forging
Avoid unvalidated input in array indexes
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
Avoid using compound assignment operators in cases which may cause overflow
Avoid unvalidated input in array indexes
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
Always check parameters before use in array access
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
Exclude unsanitized user input from format strings
Use secure communication with 'wss' (WebSocket Secure) instead of 'ws'
Do not access or set System properties
Use a Context Object to manage HTTP request parameters
Avoid calling methods and constructors which do not allow you to specify a character encoding option
Do not assume that a Java char fully represents a Unicode code point
Avoid using "." as a regular expression in 'String.replaceAll()' and 'String.replaceFirst()'
Avoid calculations which result in overflow or NaN
Do not use an integer outside the range of [0, 31] as the amount of a shift
Do not cast primitive data types to lower precision
Avoid using compound assignment operators in cases which may cause overflow
Avoid wraparounds when performing arithmetic integer operations
Use unsigned right shift instead of division when overflow is possible
Do not use an integer outside the range of [0, 31] as the amount of a shift
Avoid wraparounds when performing arithmetic integer operations
Avoid off-by-one errors in loop conditions
Avoid data loss when converting between integer types
Provide methods to read and write little-endian data
Do not pass exception messages into output in order to prevent the application from leaking sensitive information
Prevent exposure of sensitive data
Do not call the 'printStackTrace()' method of "Throwable" objects
Avoid calling print methods of 'System.err' or 'System.out'
Avoid declaring "transient" fields in non-serializable classes
Do not log confidential or sensitive information
Avoid debug information from Spring Security framework to logs
Protect against File names injection
Avoid using native JDBC
Do not use sockets in EJBs
Do not call 'Socket.setSocketImplFactory()' or 'URL.setURLStreamHandlerFactory()' in a web component
Do not use sockets in web components
Limit the number of "AccessController.doPrivileged" calls per class
Limit the number of lines in "privileged" code blocks
Consistently check the returned value of non-void methods
Check the return value of methods which read or skip input
Avoid storing usernames and passwords in plain text in Castor 'jdo-conf.xml' files
Ensure that passwords are not stored as plaintext and are sufficiently long
Ensure that passwords are not stored as plaintext and are sufficiently long
Avoid storing unencrypted Hibernate usernames and passwords in 'web.xml' files
Avoid unencrypted passwords in WebSphere 'ibm-webservicesclient-ext.xmi' files
Avoid unencrypted passwords in WebSphere 'ibm-webservices-ext.xmi' files
Password information should not be included in properties file in plaintext
Protect against using unprotected credentials
Avoid using plain text passwords in Axis 'wsdd' files
Avoid using plain text passwords in Axis2 configuration files
Ensure that passwords are not stored as plaintext and are sufficiently long
Avoid using plain text passwords in Axis2 configuration files
Avoid using cryptographic keys which are too short
Avoid setting the write or execute file permissions to unintended users
Do not rely on IP addresses obtained from HTTP request headers for authentication
Ensure the HostnameVerifier.verify() method validates the certificate
Properly validate server identity
Ensure that an appropriate security manager is set
Ensure sufficient protection against multiple failed authentication attempts
Ensure that passwords are not stored as plaintext and are sufficiently long
Prevent exposure of sensitive data
Ensure that passwords are not stored as plaintext and are sufficiently long
Password information should not be included in properties file in plaintext
Avoid storing sensitive data in plaintext in a cookie
Use the SSL-enabled version of classes when possible
Use 'https' instead of 'http' for the 'transportReceiver' and 'transportSender' in 'axis2.xml' configuration files
Avoid using hard-coded cryptographic keys
MessageDigest objects must process the data with the 'update' method
Initialize KeyGenerator instances
Avoid using custom MessageDigest implementations
Avoid using insecure cryptographic algorithms for data encryption with Spring
Avoid using insecure cryptographic algorithms in Spring XML configurations
Avoid using insecure algorithms for cryptography
Use hash functions with a salt
Use 'java.security.SecureRandom' instead of 'java.util.Random' or 'Math.random()'
Avoid using the javax.crypto.NullCipher class in non-test classes
Ensure arguments passed to certain methods come from predefined methods list
Avoid non-random "byte[]" when using IvParameterSpec
Ensure arguments passed to certain methods come from predefined methods list
Ensure arguments passed to certain methods come from predefined methods list
Use 'java.security.SecureRandom' instead of 'java.util.Random' or 'Math.random()'
Restrict cross-origin resource sharing to secure origins
Always verify JarFile signatures
Avoid DNS lookups for decision making
Protect against HTTP response splitting
Protect against XSS vulnerabilities
Use the ''getSecure()'' and ''setSecure()'' methods to enforce the use of secure cookies
Do not disable CSRF protection
Do not disable CSRF protection
